Geography

Located amongst rich farmland between the Garleton Hills and the Lammermuir Hills (which border the Southern Uplands)
column2: Haddington is an affluent county town
column3:
although their are pockets of poverty in its public housing estates.

The flooding of the River Tyne has always proven a problem in Haddington. Records show a devastating flood in the 14th Century A plaque on the corner of the High Street and Sidegate shows the height of the flood in 1775 but worse than that was in 1948 when the river rose more than 3m (10 feet) above its banks and flooded 450 homes. Emergency accommodation had to be provided using the army camp at Amisfield Park.

Haddington is twinned with the French town of Aubigny-sur-Nère
column4: which has Scottish connections going back to the 15th C.
column5: having been given to Sir John Stuart of Darnley
column6: after the Scots Army assisted the French by defeating the English at Vieil Baugé in 1421. Subsequent to the twinning in 1965
column7: a significant number of cultural and educational exchanges have taken place.

column1:
History

The origin of the name Haddington has given rise to debate
column4: after the mythical founder of the Danish kingdom. The town is important in history which often formed the 'front line' to English attack. Created a Royal Burgh sometime after the accession of David I in 1124
column6: including the ability to raise customs duties and royal patronage
column7: both of which brought wealth to the town. Between the late 12th C. and its destruction in 1242
column8: the town had a royal palace
column9:
which was birthplace of Alexander II (1198 - 1249).

The street pattern of the town-centre is mediaeval
column10: with the long and narrow gardens lying
column11: for example on the south side of High Street
column12:
providing evidence of 'riggs' from the same period.

Haddington was an important religious centre on the pilgrim's route between St. Andrews and Santiago de Compostella in Spain. St. Mary's became a collegiate church
column13: attracting religious scholars. The ruin of St Martins
column15: represents the only visible remnant of a great Cistercian Nunnery founded in 1178 by Ada de Warenne
column16: who had been given the town as a wedding present by her father-in-law David I. In 1503
column17: the young Margaret Tudor stayed here on the way to marry James IV. Edward III of England destroyed the nunnery
column19: along with much of the rest of the Scottish Borders
column20:
in 1356. St. Marys was rebuilt in the late 14th C.

The 'rough wooing' of Mary Queen of Scots
column21: whereby Henry VIII of England intended to ensure her marriage to his son
column22: brought about the Treaty of Haddington. This was signed in Haddington in 1548
column23:
within ear-shot of Henry's army which was besieging the town. The treaty brought French assistance in return for Mary's betrothal to the Dauphin of France.

Historic country seats in the vicinity include Lennoxlove
column24: home of the Duke of Hamilton

column1:
Industry

Haddington is an important market town
column2: lying amongst the rich agricultural land of East Lothian. It was the first and most significant grain market in Scotland from the late 18th until the mid-19th Century There was a 18th Century granary and maltings at Poldrate Mill
column3: now restored as a community centre. Lying across the Victoria Bridge
column5: which were significantly extended in the 19th Century and are still operating as Pure Malt. Wool processing and cloth manufacture is first recorded in 1681
column6: bringing mills and dye-works which took advantage of the River Tyne as a power-source. Hand-loom weaving continued into the latter part of the 20th Century as did another traditional industry
column7:
with the last tannery closing in the 1960s.

The railway once came to Haddington
column10: its spirit remains in the names of Station Road and the Railway Hotel in the west of the town. The railway did little for Haddington
column11: being the terminus of a branch line
column12:
it diverted traffic from the road from the south which had brought important trade to the town.

The Japanese company Mitsubishi opened a colour television plant at Gateside
column13: on the west of the town
column14: in 1978. This quickly became a major employer
column15:
but closed in 1998 with the loss of more than 500 jobs. The site has subsequently been redeveloped to provide much-needed industrial accommodation.

Today
column16: Haddington is a major administrative centre
column17: home to the local government headquarters
column18: which is the town's major employer. Tourism is important
column19: with attractions such as the 15th Century St. Mary's Kirk
column20: with historic castles such as Lennoxlove and Hailes closeby
column21: although the town is bypassed by the main A1 road
column22: which was reconstructed as a fast dual-carriageway in 1996. Other contemporary industries include electrical
column23: electronics and retailing. There is a regular farmer's market.

column3:
or East Lothian.
